patient_information: A 35-year-old Peruvian male logging supervisor. Past medical history included hepatitis of unknown etiology 20 years prior.
history_of_present_illness: Eight days prior to presentation, he developed fever and retro-orbital headache. Two days into the illness, he was admitted to a local hospital in the jungle after developing jaundice, coffee-ground vomiting, gross haematuria, and increasing mental obtundation. During transfer to the referral hospital in Lima, the patient had a generalized seizure.
exposure_and_epidemiology: Born in Lima, Peru. For the past 5 years, he has been working as a logging supervisor in a remote jungle area near Pucallpa on the Ucayali River. He has not taken any malaria prophylaxis and has not received any vaccinations since early childhood.
vitals: Temperature 38.8°C (101.8°F), blood pressure 110/70 mmHg, heart rate 110 bpm, respiratory rate 24 bpm.
physical_exam: Agitated, unresponsive to verbal commands, intermittently stuporous. Marked flapping of hands, no focal neurological signs or meningeal signs. Jaundiced. Spontaneous bleeding of oral mucosa and at venipuncture and IV sites. Multiple large ecchymoses on the face, trunk, and all limbs. Crepitant rales in both lung bases. Normal heart sounds. Liver palpable 3 cm below the right costal margin. Spleen not palpable, no lymphadenopathy.
labs_and_diagnostics: Haematocrit: 30% (Reference: 41–53%); White cell count: 8700/μL (Reference: 4500–11000/μL) (Bands: 4%, Neutrophils: 62%, Eosinophils: 0%, Basophils: 0%, Monocytes: 6%, Lymphocytes: 28%); Platelets: 110000/μL (Reference: 150000–450000/μL); AST (GOT): 2890 U/L (Reference: 0–35 U/L); ALT (GPT): 2676 U/L (Reference: 0–35 U/L); AP: 496 U/L (Reference: 38–126 U/L); Total Bilirubin: 11.6 mg/dL (Reference: 0.3–1.2 mg/dL); Direct Bilirubin: 9.2 mg/dL (Reference: 0–0.4 mg/dL); Urea: 89 mg/dL (Reference: 17–49 mg/dL); Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL (Reference: 0.6–1.2 mg/dL); Glucose: 80 mg/dL (Reference: 70–110 mg/dL); Serum Protein: 4.2 g/L (Reference: 5.5–8.0 g/L); Albumin: 2.8 g/L (Reference: 3.5–5.5 g/L); Prothrombin Time: 17 s (Reference: 11.1–13.1 s); INR: 2.6 (Reference: 0.9–1.3); aPTT: 80 s (Reference: 22.1–35.1 s); Fibrinogen: 250 mg/dL (Reference: 150–400 mg/dL); CK: 6200 U/L (Reference: 52–336 U/L); Urine: Proteins 3+, RBC: 50–60/f, WBC: 4–6/f. Malaria thick film: negative (three times). Blood cultures: negative. Brucella serology: negative. Hepatitis B IgM anti-HBc: negative. IgM capture ELISA for yellow fever: highly positive at 1:10000. Anti-dengue IgM: negative. Direct viral isolation in culture (blood specimen on admission): negative. Chest x-ray showed bilateral pulmonary infiltrates compatible with ARDS. Repeat laboratory results on day 3: creatinine 6.5 mg/dL, urea 120 mg/dL, AST 100 U/L, ALT 200 U/L.
differential_diagnosis: Severe malaria, viral hepatitis (A, B, C, D, E), toxin-mediated hepatitis, leptospirosis, typhoid fever, brucellosis, severe dengue, other viral haemorrhagic fevers (especially yellow fever).
management_and_clinical_course: The patient received presumptive treatment for malaria, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and supportive care. Over the next 3 days, he developed increasing hepatic encephalopathy, renal failure, coma, and DIC with increasing spontaneous bleeding. A chest x-ray showed bilateral pulmonary infiltrates compatible with ARDS. Repeat laboratory results on day 3 showed deterioration of kidney function (creatinine 6.5 mg/dL, urea 120 mg/dL) and a sudden drop in liver transaminases (AST 100 U/L, ALT 200 U/L), likely indicating acute hepatic disintegration. The patient passed away 1 day later.
